metadata.title: Simplistic thermal transformation of MIL-125 to TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds for efficient quantum-dot sensitized solar cells

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/mssp
Simplistic thermal transformation of MIL-125 to TiO2 nano-coins and nanodiamonds for efficient quantum-dot sensitized solar cells
Muhammad Abdul Basita,*, Muhammad Rashidb, Talha Farooq Khana, Mohsin Muhyuddina, Sajid Butta
a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Institute of Space Technology, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan b Faculty of Fisheries and Wildlife, University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, Lahore, Pakistan
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Photoanode Quantum-dots MOFs TiO2 Solar cells PbS Heat treatment
A B S T R A C T
TiO2-based nano-coins and nano-diamonds were successfully incorporated for improved performance of PbS quantum-dot sensitized solar cells (QDSCs) through a simplistic thermal transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti). We report a modified heat-treatment process which affirms simple transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) to TiO2 in addition to the removal of organic constituents of screen-printed TiO2 photoanoade, eliminating the discrete heat-treatment cycle for thermal transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) before screen-printing. X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD) revealed the phase transformation and resultant crystal structures of TiO2 while XPS was used to authenticate the fabrication of PbS sensitized TiO2 photoanode. UV–Vis spectroscopy showed that the modified photoanodes with TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds exhibited improved reflectance of light, which resulted in enhanced visible light absorbance in PbS QDs. Relatively, incorporation of simplistically transformed TiO2 nano-diamonds resulted higher photocurrent density (JSC~17mA/cm2) in QDSCs which was credited to superior absorbance of incident light and inferior charge carrier recombination.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Out of so many photovoltaic (PV) technologies, dye or quantum-dot sensitized solar cells (DSCs/QDSCs) are emerging as cost-effective and easily fabricable PV devices [1,2]. Apart from a few differences, including the type of electrolyte, sensitizer, and counter electrode, the overall scheme and construction of these PV cells are the same. In particular, DSCs as well as QDSCs comprise of a mesoporous film of high band gap semiconducting oxide material (e.g. TiO2), either sensitized by organic dyes such as N719 [3,4] or by quantum-dots (QD) such as PbS [5–8]. Mainly, mesoporous TiO2 film is composed of ~20–50 nm sized particles [4,9]. However, it has been established that the incorporation of various morphologies of TiO2 together with nanoparticles resulted in increased power conversion efficiency (PCE) of DSCs [10,11]. Such improvement in the performance of DSCs is credited to better light harvesting or charge carrier transfer characteristics of photoanodes [12–18]. For instance, Son et al. [19] mixed ~250 nmsized SiO2/TiO2 core-shell particles in conventional TiO2 photoanode to produce backscattering of light and thus more absorbance within dyemolecules. Using the aforementioned strategy, the charge carrier generation and PCE of DSCs were significantly improved, and it proved
equally effectual for QDSCs as well [3,20,21]. A variety of materials and their geometrically efficient morphologies are reported for the efficient backscattering of incident light in DSCs and QDSCs [8,19,22,23], however, TiO2 is the most extensively reported one owing to its optoelectronic compatibility with conventional TiO2 [4,6,9,24–28].
One of the best routes to develop diverse morphologies of TiO2 is based on thermal decomposition of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [29]. Using the fact that the morphology and size of such TiO2 particles play the main role in the optoelectronic characteristics of photoanodes, Chi et al. [20] utilized coin-like and diamond-like TiO2 particles derived from NH2-MIL-125(Ti) for increased light harvesting tendency of TiO2 photoanodes in DSCs. It resulted in improved photocurrent density (JSC) from ~11mA/cm2 to 17mA/cm2 and ~19mA/cm2 respectively. However, they reported multiple heat-treatments before, during and after the fabrication of TiO2 photoanode. NH2-MIL-125(Ti) was first transformed into hierarchical TiO2 (hier-TiO2) separately and then applied onto the nanocrystalline TiO2 through screen-printing followed by another heat-treatment to remove the organic binders of screenprinted photoanode. Contrarily, we eliminated the additional thermal calcination process for the transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) before applying it onto the photoanode. The thermal transformation of NH2-
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mssp.2019.104663 Received 22 June 2019; Received in revised form 30 July 2019; Accepted 1 August 2019
* Corresponding author., E-mail addresses: ab_saim@hotmail.com, m.abdulbasit@mail.ist.edu.pk (M.A. Basit).
Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing 104 (2019) 104663
1369-8001/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
MIL-125(Ti) to TiO2 was obtained alongside the heat-treatment of screen-printed TiO2. Simply transformed TiO2 layer comprised of TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds effectually served as light scattering layer (SL) to improve the light absorbance inside PbS QDs. Consequently, the JSC and PCE of QDSCs were significantly improved. Corresponding TiO2 morphologies were observed using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), while crystallographic characteristics were studied using x-ray diffraction (XRD) and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Improved light scattering and enhanced absorbance inside TiO2 photoanodes were confirmed by ultraviolet–visible (UV-Vis) absorbance characteristics.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of NH2-MIL-125(Ti)
sections.text: Morphology-controlled NH2-MIL-125(Ti) crystals were synthesized using a previously reported method [30]. Typically, 2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (NH2-BDC) and TTIP (i.e., Titanium Isopropoxide) were dissolved in a mixed solvent of methanol and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), with 1:9 volumetric ratio respectively. The resultant solution was vigorously stirred ultrasonically for 10min and then transferred to the 100ml teflon-lined steel autoclave. Then it was subjected to heat at 150 °C for 24 h under the fixed conditions. After cooling it down, the product was washed with DMF and methanol repeatedly and then isolated through centrifugation. The final product was dried at 50 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven (DZF6020, MTI Corporation USA). For making two different morphologies of NH2-MIL125(Ti) crystals, the concentration was modulated by varying the total solvent volume. NH2-MIL-125(Ti) (written as MIL-125 hereafter) crystals synthesized in 30ml and 20ml solution were (respectively written as MIL-1 and MIL-2 onwards) used to make their screen-printable pastes in accordance with previous reports [6,31].

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of photoanodes
sections.text: Fluorine-doped tinoxide (FTO) coated glass substrates were successively cleaned using dilute hydrochloric acid and acetone first. Later, secondary cleaning was done by ethanol and deionized water (DIW) for 20min each. For reference sample, 5 cycles of commercial TiO2 paste (T/SP Solaronix Ti-Nanoxide) were screen-printed on FTO coated glass [5,32] resulting in nearly ~15μm thick film [6]. While for modified samples, 3 cycles of commercial TiO2 paste were screen-printed and then coupled with 2 cycles of pastes prepared from MIL-1 and MIL-2. Later, all screen-printed FTO glass substrates were calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in order to decompose the organic binders associated with the deposited pastes. Additively, the same heat-treatment facilitated the transformation of MIL-1 and MIL-2 into coin and diamond shaped hierTiO2 with a large surface area. Later, successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction (SILAR) was adopted to sensitize TiO2 photoanodes with PbS QDs [5–7,32–34]. Briefly, TiO2 photoanodes were exposed to anionic-lead and cationic-sulfur precursors having 0.02M solutions in methanol and water/methanol solvent for 1min respectively [5,6]. Before and after each ionic immersion, photoanodes were rinsed in methanol to remove loosely adsorbed and/or unreacted ions. This 4 step SILAR cycle was repeated thrice for optimum PbS QDs deposition [6,7]. Lastly, ZnS was deposited using 0.05M solutions of Zn+2 and S−2. Two SILAR cycles of ZnS passivation layer are most abundantly applied passivation layer in QDSCs. Lastly, the samples were heattreated at 250 °C for half an hour [33,34].

sections.heading: 2.3. Solar cell assembly
sections.text:
Commonly used CuS-deposited FTO glass was used as a counter electrode [19,35]. Before coupling the photoanode and the counter electrode together, a surlyn film was placed and melted around
photoanode by heat-treating at 90 °C for 5min. As soon as surlyn separator was cooled down to room temperature, a polysulfide electrolyte comprising of 0.25M S and 0.625M Na2S in methanol and DIW having 2:3 volumetric ratio was poured dropwise on each QDs-sensitized TiO2 photoanode. Finally, both electrodes were firmly seized together by means of clips and characterized further.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterizations
sections.text: MIRA-3 modeled field emission type scanning electron microscope (FESEM, TESCAN) was used to observe the morphological characteristics of MIL-125 and fabricated photoanodes developed using coin and diamond shaped hier-TiO2. Alongside the FESEM, an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) detector was employed to obtain compositional details of relevant photoanodes. For revealing the phase transformation and resultant crystal structures of TiO2, X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD, Explorer, GNR Analytical) was employed. XPS (Thermo Scientific Escalab-250xi equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiations) was employed to determine the chemical state, based upon binding energy, of each element present. The obtained data was calibrated using C 1s reference peak at ~284.8eV. The as-acquired data was deconvoluted after applying smart background (shirely + linear). Keithley 2400 modeled source meter was used to record photocurrent density-voltage (J-V) and open-circuit voltage decay (OCVD) characteristics of QDSCs. While using a silicon diode (CS-20, Asahi Spectra), the intensity of light to one sun was regulated through solar simulator (HAL-320, Asahi Spectra). SCINCO S-3100 type spectrophotometer coupled with a diffuse reflector was employed to determine the reflectance and absorbance response of various photoanodic films.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows FESEM images of MIL-125(Ti) crystals synthesized by altering the concentration of the reactants [20,30]. At lower concentration i.e. 30ml of NH2-BDC and TTIP solution, a circular plate-like morphology (Fig. 1a and b) was obtained which is hereafter termed as MIL-1. At higher concentration, i.e. 20ml solution, MIL-2 having octahedral morphology (Fig. 1c and d) was obtained. Owing to the fact that MIL-125 transforms to TiO2 on heating [36] while it sustains its morphology, MIL-1 and MIL-2 were employed for light scattering [4,24,37] and better absorbance of light inside dye/QDs sensitized photoanodes after apposite heat-treatment. Fig. 2 compares the conventional and modified route for the incorporation of MIL-125 in TiO2 photoanodes. As shown in Fig. 2a, MIL-125 was previously converted first to hier-TiO2 (either MIL-1 or MIL-2) through heat-treatment at 380 °C for an extended time of 5 h (ΔH1), and then, hier-TiO2 were deposited as scattering layers (SL) over screen-printed nanocrystalline TiO2. These photoanodes were again heat-treated at 50 °C and 80 °C for 1 h each, and then finally calcined at 500 °C for 30min (ΔH4) to remove the binders inside the screen-printed pastes [20]. But in the modified route, we directly deposited MIL-125 in the form of MIL-1 and MIL-2 over nanocrystalline TiO2 and then the photoanode was subjected to heat-treatment for one time only at 500 °C for 2 h, resulting in the transformation of MIL-1 and MIL-2 into hier-TiO2 and the removal of organic binders, as depicted in Fig. 2b. The modified route enabled us to diminish a series of heat-treatments, particularly ΔH1. Fig. 3(a–d) shows FESEM images of MIL-1 and MIL-2 crystals which have undergone transformation from pure MIL-125 to hier-TiO2 nanostructures after heat-treatment at 500 °C for 2 h. MIL-1 (Fig. 3a and b) and MIL-2 (Fig. 3c and d) maintained their shapes after heat-treatment but they transformed into hier-TiO2 nanostructures, and those are respectively named as TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds hereafter. Upon thermal transformation, a slight reduction in the size of TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds was observed as compared to MIL-1 and MIL-2. After heat-treatment, the average sizes of TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds came out to be roughly around 300 nm and 500 nm, which can
be appreciated in FESEM images. Chi et al. [20] and Wang et al. [36] reported that this reduction in size is due to the formation of pores associated with the decomposition of frameworks of intertwined Ti metal and organic linkers. It is well known that the amount of QDs/dye is reduced inside the photoanode by increasing the particle size of TiO2 or scattering particles, therefore it can be speculated that TiO2 nanocoins or TiO2 nano-diamonds having pores inside can somewhat compensate the deposition of QDs/dye [3], which will be discussed later. XRD analysis was done to optimize the heat-treatment cycle for MIL125 incorporated TiO2 photoanodes. Fig. 3e shows that MIL-125 started transforming to TiO2 after 400 °C and exhibited significant crystallinity after it was heat-treated at 500 °C for 2 h. We can see the XRD patterns corresponding to MIL-125, TiO2 nano-coins and TiO2 nano-diamonds at different temperatures, which are consistent with earlier reported results [20,38,39]. Crystallographically, MIL-125 mainly consists of μ-OH corner-sharing TiO6 octahedral chains through Ti4+ ions which are interlocked by NH2-BDC molecules to evolve three-dimensional architecture pores [30]. As clearly shown in Fig. 3e, MIL-125 preserved its
crystal structure till 300 °C and the main diffracted peaks were observed at angles (2θ) of 6.7°, 9.7°, 11.6°, 15.0°, 15.3°, 16.5°, 17.9° 19.5°, and 20°, which are in agreement with the previous reports [40–42]. After heat-treatment at 500 °C for 2 h, MIL-125 fully transformed into hierTiO2 with major anatase phase (as shown in Fig. S1). The peaks observed at 25.3°, 37.9°, 47.8°, and 54.7° corresponds to (101), (004), (200), and (105) crystal planes of TiO2 respectively, which are again well-matched with anatase-TiO2 [43,44]. Once the thermal transformation was affirmed, respective photoanodes (Fig. S2) were used for optical characterization and PbS-based QDs-sensitization, respectively. Fig. 4a shows that the presence of hier-TiO2, whether TiO2 nano-coins or TiO2 nano-diamonds increased the reflectance as compared to nanocrystalline TiO2 which is credited to the scattering of incident light [20]. The relation between the scattering of the light and the size of scattering particles is mathematically described as;
=x πr λ 2 (1)
where ‘r’ refers to the size of the particle (generally radius of the
sphere), ‘λ’ is the wavelength of light and ‘x’ denotes the non-dimensional size parameter. When x ~1 (i.e. the scattering particles are nanosized) the active scattering regime is termed as Mie scattering which governs the scattering of light from solar spectrum. Particles ranging from ~100 nm to 1 μm or more have been used previously to modify such scattering of light, either in ultraviolet, or visible or infra-red range of incident radiation. Similarly, we observed uplift in the visible light reflectance as well absorbance from ~400 nm onwards for photoanodes having TiO2 nano-coins as well as TiO2 nano-diamonds. Fig. 4b shows that the increase in the scattering of light increases the probability of contact between the light and thoroughly disseminated QDs inside mesoporous TiO2 due to enhanced light path [6,20,27]. The absorbance characteristics (Fig. 4c) further revealed that TiO2 nanodiamonds had more absorbance compared to nanocrystalline-TiO2 as well as TiO2 nano-coins which is credited to higher reflectance as well
as superior deposition of PbS QDs (inset Fig. 4c) as revealed by EDS in Fig. S3.
PbS-sensitized TiO2 photoanode having diamond-like shape was further investigated using XPS. The high resolution Ti 2p spectrum comprised of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 doublets separated by spin-orbitsplitting (S.O.S.) value of 5.63eV, is shown in Fig. 5a. The presence of Ti 2p3/2 peak at 458.50 eV corresponds to the existence of TiO2 phase [45,46]. The presence of pure TiO2 phase could also be supported by a shallow peak appearing at 530.07eV in the O 1s spectrum, as shown in Fig. 5b. It simply authenticates that the modified heat-treatment route for the incorporation of MIL worked well for TiO2 photoanode as there is an obvious evolution of TiO2 and none of detrimental reaction is byproduced. Similarly, the high resolution Pb 4f doublet was deconvoluted using synthetic peaks. For the Pb 4fp7/2 peak, the two synthetic peaks appearing at 136.55eV and 137.49eV are corresponding to the
possible presence of PbS [22,45] and lead oxide (Pb-O) phases, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5c. Such oxides originate from wet chemical route of deposition (i.e., SILAR) and heat-treatment of PbS-sensitized TiO2 photoanode at 250 °C for 30min. It is important to understand that XPS is a surface sensitive technique (i.e., penetration depth less than 10 nm). Since these oxides are evolved over the surface of sulfides at nanoscale, therefore these oxides would have been over-estimated and thus exhibited higher peak intensities than sulfides. But, it has been widely accepted that these oxides have a tendency to transform back when exposed to polysulfide electrolyte during cell assembly [8,22] and cast no significant detriment during the working of a QDSC. Since a passivation layer of ZnS was deposited on PbS-sensitized TiO2 photoanode having TiO2 nano-coins as well as nano-diamonds using SILAR, Fig. 5d shows the high resolution Zn 2p spectrum for Zn, which depicts the presence of ZnS and ZnO as supported by synthetic peaks appearing at 1020.37eV and 1022.07eV, respectively, drawn under Zn 2p3/2. The presence of metal oxides is also clear from a strong and broad peak appearing at 532.88eV, as shown in Fig. 5b. The deconvolution reveals the presence of Pb-O and ZnO signatures in the sample.
Once the newly routed fabrication of TiO2 nano-coins and TiO2 nano-diamonds incorporated photoanodes was confirmed qualitatively as well quantitatively, all photoanodes were assembled as solar cells and their photovoltaic behavior was evaluated. Fig. 6a shows the typical photocurrent density-voltage curves for QDSCs, indicating uplift in the photocurrent density of TiO2 nano-coins and TiO2 nano-diamonds incorporated QDSCs compared to nanocrystalline TiO2 based QDSC. The JSC of nanocrystalline TiO2 was found to be ~12mA/cm2 (PCE~2.21%) which increased to ~14 (PCE ~2.76%) and 17mA/cm2
(PCE ~3.17%) for TiO2 nano-coins and TiO2 nano-diamonds incorporated QDSCs, respectively. This increase in JSC values can be justified by the previously discussed results obtained through UV–Vis spectroscopy and EDS. TiO2 nano-diamonds based photoanodes, due to having more absorbance (Fig. 4c), which could be credited to higher scattering of light along with superior QDs loading as indicated in the inset of Fig. 4c obtained by analyzing the elemental ratios from EDS (Fig. S3), showed the highest photocurrent density. Moreover, the
enhanced visible light absorbance inside photoanode directly increases the electron-hole generation [27,47] and thus lifts up the PCE at standard incidence of light.
An increase in JSC owing to superior deposition of PbS QDs inside QDSCs also affects the electron transfer dynamics at TiO2/PbS/electrolyte interface. Although, electrochemical impedence spectroscopy (EIS) is stronger tool to reveal various electrochemical characteristics (such as electron life time etc.), however we employed OCVD technique due to stability issues of PbS based QDSCs. Simply, all QDSCs were irradiated for 10s so that maximum voltage is developed and then the light source was switched off. The voltage drops were recorded which showed the lowest rate of voltage-decay for QDSC having TiO2 nanodiamonds (Fig. 6b). It was previously proved that higher deposition of PbS QDs inside mesoporous TiO2 reduces the direct contact between the electrolyte and TiO2 [6,7,26]. Resultantly, the back transfer of electron to electrolyte is reduced. The reduction in back transfer of electrons is inversely related to electron-hole recombination but directly proportional to electron life [6,8,26,27]. Therefore, it can be speculated that reduced OCVD rates for modified TiO2 photoanodes improved the electrochemical characteristics such as electron life time etc. That is why TiO2 nano-diamond incorporated QDSCs which had more PbS QDs deposited inside showed lower OCVD rate. Increase in the (open circuit voltage) Voc from 0.46V (PCE ~2.21%) to 0.47V (PCE ~2.76%) and ~0.49V (PCE ~3.17%) respectively for TiO2 nano-coins and TiO2 nanodiamonds is credited to decrease in charge carrier recombination.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, we reported more efficient thermal transformation route for incorporating metal-organic framework based morphologies as light scattering particles quantum-dot-sensitized solar cells (QDSCs). Firstly, thermal transformation of MIL-125 to TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds was affirmed, reducing the heat-treatment cycle significantly. Secondly, it was revealed that both hier-TiO2 worked as efficient light scattering layers (SLs) in PbS based QDSCs. Increased absorbance of light inside PbS QDs, credited to back scattering of light
from SLs enabled TiO2 photoanode to produce higher photocurrent density (JSC) than standard QDSC without SL. TiO2 nano-diamonds SL showed the optimal performance which was ascribed to improved electron transfer dynamics at TiO2/PbS QDs/electrolyte interface as revealed by OCVD.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.mssp.2019.104663.

metadata.abstractText: TiO2-based nano-coins and nano-diamonds were successfully incorporated for improved performance of PbS quantum-dot sensitized solar cells (QDSCs) through a simplistic thermal transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti). We report a modified heat-treatment process which affirms simple transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) to TiO2 in addition to the removal of organic constituents of screen-printed TiO2 photoanoade, eliminating the discrete heat-treatment cycle for thermal transformation of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) before screen-printing. X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD) revealed the phase transformation and resultant crystal structures of TiO2 while XPS was used to authenticate the fabrication of PbS sensitized TiO2 photoanode. UV–Vis spectroscopy showed that the modified photoanodes with TiO2 nano-coins and nano-diamonds exhibited improved reflectance of light, which resulted in enhanced visible light absorbance in PbS QDs. Relatively, incorporation of simplistically transformed TiO2 nano-diamonds resulted higher photocurrent density (JSC~17mA/cm) in QDSCs which was credited to superior absorbance of incident light and inferior charge carrier recombination.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
